Fukushima Daiichi: The plants were not designed with consideration of such a large tsunami. A major earthquake and tsunami caused the destruction of power lines and backup generators. Once the plants were without external power and the generators were flooded  a catastrophic decay heat casualty ensued  leading to major reactor plant damage including meltdowns and explosive loss of reactor containment.
Chernobyl: Proximate cause was human error and violation of procedures. The unsafe reactor design caused instability at low power due to a positive void coefficient and steam formation. When an improper test was conducted at 1:00 am at low power  the reactor became prompt critical. This was followed by a steam explosion that exposed the fuel  a raging fire  and a core meltdown. The fire lasted for days to weeks  and there is controversy over whether it was the fuel burning  nuclear decay heating or whether the graphite moderator that made up most of the core was involved. See Chernobyl Disaster  Note 1  for more discussion.
